children.name: to hit sb/sth with your foot
kick a1
children.definition: kick to hit sb/sth with your foot
examples: the boy behind me kept kicking my chair.
he was dragged kicking and screaming into a waiting police car.
i could feel the baby kicking inside me.
kick something down/over/around etc
billy was kicking a ball around the yard.
the police kicked the door down.
who kicked the ball over the fence?
kick somebody in the stomach/face/shin etc
there was a scuffle and he kicked me in the stomach.
kick[c] a2 a kicking action or movement:
one karate kick can kill someone.
and what a tremendous kick that was - straight into the goal from 200 yards.
give sb/sth a kick[]to kick sb/sthonce:đá cho phát
he gave the bundle a gentle kick, but still it didn’t move.
give sth a good kickkick it hard
if the door won’t open, just give it a good hard kick.

children.name: knee x
children.definition: knee/niː/  to hit someone using one of your knees:
examples: đầu gối
▪ she struggled free and kneed her attacker in the groin.

children.name: boot x
children.definition: boot  to kick sb/sth hard, especially a ball:
examples: he booted the ball up to the other end of the playing field.
suddenly this big heavy guy came up and booted me in the stomach.
they booted himinthe head.

children.name: hit a2
children.definition: hit/hɪt/
examples: ▪ be careful with that stick! you nearly hit me with it.

children.name: bang x
children.definition: bang/bash/bæŋ, bæʃ/  to hit someone or something hard, often making a noise and hurting someone or damaging something: tông , đập, va
examples: bang your head/knee/elbow etc
▪ i banged my head getting into the car.
bang something into/against/on etc something
▪ tom bashed his knee against the table.
▪ he slipped, banging his guitar against the door.
bang/bash into/against
▪ kids raced around the playground, banging into each other, screaming, and letting off steam.

children.name: collide x
children.definition: collide if two people or things collide, they accidentally hit each other when they are moving in different directions: va vào nhau, đụng nhau
examples: ▪ barker and mason collided while going for the ball.
▪ when the plates of land that form the earth collide or slide past each other, earthquakes result.
collide with
▪ i backed out of the door and promptly collided with someone. ‘i’m sorry,’ i said.

children.name: crash into b1
children.definition: crash into to hit sb/sth extremely hard, especially while moving very fast: lao vào, va vào
examples: ▪ tyler injured his shoulder when he crashed into jesse lyons during practice.

children.name: bump b2
children.definition: bump/bʌmp/  to accidentally and suddenly hit part of your body against something:
examples: bump your head/elbow/knee etc
▪ babies are always bumping their heads.
bump against
▪ his right leg bumped against the parking brake.
bump into[verb phrase] if you bump into something or someone, you hit them with part of your body accidentally when you are walking or running somewhere: va vào ai
▪ jim turned suddenly and bumped into me.

children.name: strike b1
children.definition: strike/straɪk/  formal if something, especially a heavy object, strikes something or someone, it hits them hard once:
examples: ▪ a house nearby had been struck by a falling tree.
▪ the ball struck him in the face.

children.name: knock b1
children.definition: knock/nɒkǁnɑːk/  to hit someone or something with a short quick movement:
examples: ▪ she knocked me with her elbow as she passed.
knock against
▪ the heavy video camera knocked against his hip as he walked.
knock into
▪ she turned and ran, knocking into bystanders as she went.
knock something against/into something
▪ one of the movers knocked the sofa against a doorway.

children.name: crack x
children.definition: crack/kræk/  to hit your head, knee, elbow etc hard and painfully against something:
examples: crack something on/against something
▪ he slipped and cracked his head on the steps.
▪ mary cracked her knee on the corner of her desk.

children.name: blow c2
children.definition: blow a hard hit with someone’s hand, a tool, or a weapon : cú đánh, đòn
examples: the blow proved fatal.
she died from aheavy blowto the head.
martinreceived a blowon the nose.
he had been struck aglancing blow(= a blow that did not hit him directly )by the car.
blow to
he gave her a violent blow to the head.
strike (sb) a blow
the assailant struck several blows before he was restrained.
officer stacey was knocked over by a sharp blow to the head.
he struck a blow which threw her to the floor.
registerin everyday english, people usually say that someonegets hitor that somethinghitsthem, rather than using the nounblow:
hereceived a blow tothe head.➔hegot hit onthe head.

children.name: impact c2
children.definition: impact when one object hits another : va chạm
examples: just after the impact there was a flash as the rocket exploded.
on impact
both cars burst into flames on impact.

children.name: punch b2
children.definition: punchalsosluginformal /pʌntʃ, slʌg/  to hit someonehardwith your closed hand, especially in a fight or because you are angry: đấm, thụi
examples: ▪ the woman claimed that she had been punched and kicked by one of the policemen.
▪ the actor slugged a photographer who got too close.
punch somebody on the nose/in the eye/in the chest etc
▪ dean punched her in the ribs and pushed her against the wall.
throw a punch[] b2 to hit or try to hit someone very hard with a closed hand in a fight:
▪ rogers threw a punch at martin.
▪ foreman, once the world heavyweight champion, says ‘i never throw a punch in anger.’

children.name: hit a2
children.definition: hit/hɪt/  to hit sb with your hand or with something that you are holding in your hand:
examples: ▪ dad! peter keeps hitting me!hit with
▪ the victim had been hit with a baseball bat.
hit sb on the nose/in the stomach/over the head etc
▪ there was a fight, and someone had hit him over the head with a chair.
hit somebody hardwith a lot of force
▪ he hit him hard in the stomach.
hit somebody backto hit sb when they have hit you đánh trả
▪ don’t hit him, he’ll only hit you back.

children.name: slap b2
children.definition: slap/slæp/  to hit someone, especially on their face, with the flat part of your open hand: tát
examples: ▪ i was so angry i wanted to slap him.
slap somebody across the face
▪ she slapped him across the face and stormed out of the room.
slap somebody’s face
▪ dora slapped his face and ran home.
slap[countable noun] c2
▪ if you don’t behave yourself, you’ll get a slap!

children.name: strike b1
children.definition: strike/straɪk/  formal to hit someone, especially on a particular part of their body:
examples: ▪ her husband had never struck her before.
strike with
▪ evidence shows that the victim had been struck several times with an iron bar.
strike somebody on the head/in the stomach etc
▪ the court heard that the defendant had struck payne repeatedly in the face, causing serious bruising.

children.name: whack x
children.definition: whack/wæk/  informal to hit sb hard, with your hand or with an object: đánh mạnh
examples: ▪ if he said anything like that to me, i’d whack him!

children.name: thump x
children.definition: thump/θʌmp/  informal to hit someone very hard with your closed hand, especially on their body rather than on their face or head: thụi
examples: ▪ mike thumped stephanie’s back several times to stop her choking.

children.name: bash x
children.definition: bash/bæʃ/  spoken to hit someone hard, especially in a fight: đánh mạnh
examples: bash somebody’s head/face/teeth etc in
▪ i told him i’d bash his head in if he ever touched her again.

children.name: clobber x
children.definition: clobber spoken to hit sb very hard, either with your hand or with a hard object:
examples: ▪ the kids are bored, and have nothing to do but clobber each other.

children.name: to make sb/sth fall down by hitting them
knock out b2
children.definition: knock out to hit sb so hard that they fall down and become unconscious: hạ gục
examples: ▪ jackson hit brian hard with his left fist and knocked him out.
▪ he is a good boxer, a powerful puncher who has knocked out 18 of his 20 opponents to date.
knock somebody out coldso that they become completely unconscious
▪ the blow to sergeant lewis’ head had knocked him out cold.

children.name: knock down b1
children.definition: knock down/over to hit someone or something and make them fall onto the ground - use this about people or objects hitting someone or something: đánh ngã , húc ngã, đánh đổ
examples: ▪ jo was almost knocked down by a kid on a bicycle.
▪ one boy crashed into him and knocked him over.
▪ there was a crash as the cat knocked over something in the kitchen.
get knocked down/over
▪ as the crowd rushed towards the gate, several people got knocked over.

children.name: run over b2
children.definition: run over to hit and injure apersonoranimalwhiledrivinga vehicle: tông , đâm
examples: ▪ how can you run over a child and not stop?
be run over by something
▪ the boy’s dog had been run over by a car.
get run over
▪ make sure the lights on your bike are working. i don’t want you getting run over.

children.name: punch out x
children.definition: punch out us to hit someone with your closed hand, so hard that they become unconscious:
examples: ▪ i got so mad i just wanted to punch someone out.
▪ the coach threw him off the team after he punched out a teammate.

children.name: knock off u
children.definition: knock off  to hit sth so that it falls off a surface:
examples: ▪ part of the puzzle had been knocked off onto the floor.
knock something off something
▪ ellie accidentally knocked a cup of milk off the table.

children.name: to hit an object, door, table etc with sth
bang b2
children.definition: bang/bæŋ/  to hit a door, table etc very hard with your hand or with an object, in order to attract attention or because you are angry: đập ( bàn , cửa )
examples: ▪ thomas banged his fist on the table.
bang on/at
▪ i banged at the door but nobody came.
▪ he complained loudly until val finally banged on the table and shouted at him.
bang something shutđóng sầm cửa lại
▪ sherman banged the door shut.

children.name: knock b1
children.definition: knock/nɒkǁnɑːk/  to hit adoororwindow, especially with your closed hand, in order to attract the attention of the people inside: gõ
examples: ▪ would you mind knocking before you come in?
▪ i waited a moment, then knocked again.
knock on/at
▪ lula knocked at the back door and he appeared, dressed in pyjamas.
▪ ‘mattie?’ called jerry, knocking on the door.
knock[c]
knock at/on
▪ i had just turned out the lights when i heard a knock at the door.
knocking[singular noun] the sound of someone knocking::tiếng gõ cửa
▪ we were woken by a frantic knocking at the door.

children.name: hammer x
children.definition: hammer/ˈhæməʳ/  to keep hitting something very loudly and quickly especially with your closed hand, because you are angry, impatient etc: đập , đấm mạnh
examples: hammer on/at/against
▪ the children hammered at the door to be let in out of the rain.
▪ her heart hammered against her ribs.

children.name: tap b2
children.definition: tap/tæp/  to hit something gently so that it makes a light noise, especially in order to get someone’s attention:' vỗ đập nhẹ
examples: ▪ daley read the notes, tapping a pencil on the desk.
tap on/at
▪ she tapped on the window to attract his attention.
tap[countable noun] b2
▪ i was startled by a light tap at the door.
tapverb-pp-hit
[ i or t ] to hit something gently, and often repeatedly, especially making short sharp noises
the branches tappedagainstthe window.
i could hear him tapping his fingers on the desk.
i was tapping my feet (= hitting the floor gently with my feet) to the music.
someone tapped meon the shoulder.
tapb2nounhit
[ c ] a gentle knock or touch, or the noise made by knocking something gently
i gave her a tap on the shoulder and she turned round.
there was a tap on the window - dad was outside!

children.name: hit a2
children.definition: hit/hɪt/
examples: ▪ you have to try to hit the ball over the net.
▪ the first time i tried archery, i couldn’t even hit the target.

children.name: rap x
children.definition: rap/ræp/  to hit something loudly and very quickly several times in order to attract attention:
examples: ▪ the conductor rapped the music stand with his baton and the violins stopped playing.
rap on/at
▪ seeing her son outside, mrs evans rapped on the window and called him back into the house.
rap[countable noun]
▪ there was a rap at the kitchen door.

children.name: strike b1
children.definition: strike/straɪk/  formal to hit something hard, especially in a very controlled or skilful way:
examples: ▪ morris struck his drum, and the band started to march down the street.
▪ in anger, he struck the wall with a stick.

children.name: bash x
children.definition: bashalsogive something a bashbritish /bæʃ, ˌgɪv something ə ˈbæʃ/  informal to hit something hard with your hand or with a stick, hammer etc especially in a careless way:
examples: ▪ if the television stops working, just bash it a couple of times -- that usually helps.
▪ i put the box on the floor and gave it a good bash with my hammer, but it still wouldn’t open.

children.name: whack x
children.definition: whack/wæk/  to hit something hard and noisily, especially using a flat object:
examples: ▪ buckley whacked the ball into left field.
▪ the georgia man whacked his fist on the bar.

children.name: beat up b2
children.definition: beat up to hit someone hard and repeatedly all over their body, leaving them badly hurt and often unable to move: đập tơi bời
examples: ▪ he would come home drunk, get into a fight with mom, and beat her up.
▪ carl got beaten up outside a nightclub on saturday night.

children.name: beat up on sb u
children.definition: beat up on/ˌbiːt ˈʌp ɒn/  american torepeatedlyhit someoneweakerthan yourself, for example a younger child at school:
examples: đánh tơi bời
▪ he was a bully, a mean kid who beat up on the other kids.

children.name: beat b2
children.definition: beat/biːt/  to hit sb hard and repeatedly with your hand or with sth such as a stick:
examples: ▪ it was clear that she had been badly beaten by her husband.
beat with
▪ police officers had beaten the man with their batons.
beat sb black and bluebeat someone so hard that their body is covered in marks
▪ the child had been beaten black and blue.
beat the living daylights out of sbbeat sb very hard and violently
▪ osborne wanted to beat the living daylights out of flanagan.

children.name: batter x
children.definition: batter/ˈbætəʳ/  to repeatedly hit someone in an uncontrolled and violent way:
examples: ▪ teachers suspect that the child is being battered regularly by his parents.
batter with
▪ there were reports of soldiers battering prisoners with their rifles.
batter somebody to deathuntil they are dead
▪ the jury heard how thompson had been maddened by what he saw and battered his wife to death.

children.name: knock sb about x
children.definition: knock somebody aboutbritish /knocksomebodyaroundamerican  to hit sb several times, especially in order to frighten them:
examples: ▪ my father used to knock my mother about when he was drunk.
▪ they had been threatened with a gun, pushed, shoved, and knocked around.

children.name: club x
children.definition: club/klʌb/  to hit someone very hard, especially on the head with a thick heavy object:
examples: ▪ football fans were clubbed by riot police trying to stop the violence.
club somebody to deathuntil they are dead
▪ baby seals are clubbed to death for their fur.

children.name: to hit sb in a friendly way etc
slap sb on the back b2
children.definition: slap/clap somebody on the back/ˌslæp, ˌklæp somebody ɒn ðə ˈbæk/  to hit someone on the back with the flat part of your hand, for example as a friendly greeting or in order to praise them:
examples: ▪ ‘how are you? i haven’t seen you for ages,’ she said, slapping jim on the back.
▪ the coach said ‘well done!’ and clapped each player on the back as they entered the changing room.

children.name: pat c2
children.definition: pat to gently hit someone, usually on their back, shoulder, or head, in order to praise them or show them that you like them: vỗ nhẹ
examples: ▪ roz reached over and patted her hand.
▪ he got up, patted her on the shoulder, and gave her a quick kiss.

children.name: into b1
children.definition: intoprepositiontouching forcefully
examples: used to show movement which involves something touching something else with
a lot of force but without moving inside it
_he's always walking into things when he hasn't got his glasses on.
